Maclureite.Colour: Wine yellow, Brownish yellow to nearly orange, Reddish brown
Maclureite.Cleavage: None ObservedNuttall (1822b) and Seybert (1822a) do not agree on the presence of cleavage. Nuttall indicates the presence of a lamellar and a splintery texture while Seybert (1822a)says there are two cleavages.
Comment: "It is imperfectly lamellar in one direction, splintery in the other..."
"Its gravity is a small fraction above 3."
Maclureite.Health Risks: No information on health risks for this material has been entered into the database. You should always treat mineral specimens with care.

Renardite.Name: Named in honor of Alphonse François Renard (28 September 1842, Ronse, Belgium - 9 July 1903, Elsene Belgium), geologist and petrographer at the University of Ghent, Belgium. Among other things, he studied sample from the seabed, collected from the Challenger Expedition.
8.EC.108 : PHOSPHATES, ARSENATES, VANADATESE : Uranyl phosphates and arsenatesC : UO2:RO4 = 3:2
Renardite.Elements listed: H, O, P, Pb, U - search for minerals with similar chemistry
Renardite.Morphology:
Platy, rectangular prismatic crystals parallel to (100), with a rhombic appearance.
The largest crystal described by Schoep (1928) measured 1.0 x 0.35 x 0.07 mm.
Renardite.Health Risks: No information on health risks for this material has been entered into the database. You should always treat mineral specimens with care.

Destinezite.Colour: Yellow, brownish yellow, brown, reddish brown, greenish yellow, pale green, pale yellow; pale yellow to yellowish brown in transmitted light
Destinezite.Name: Named by H. Forir and A. Jorissen in 1880 in honor of Mr. Pierre Destinez [died 7 April 1911 in Liège], a laboratory assistant at the University of Liège, Liège, Belgium. Destinez was a member of the Société Géologique de Belgique as early as 1886 and published a number of articles on paleontological subjects as late as 1904.
Destinezite.Co-Type Localities: ⓘ Argenteau, Visé, Liège, Wallonia, Belgiumⓘ Alum Cave Bluff, Sevier Co., Tennessee, USA
8.DB.058 : PHOSPHATES, ARSENATES, VANADATESD : Phosphates, etc. with additional anions, with H2OB : With only medium-sized cations, (OH, etc.):RO4< 1:1

Destinezite.Morphology: Rarely microcrystalline comprised of six-sided platy crystals.

Beaumontite (of L\u00e9vy).Name: Named in 1839 by M. Lévy in honor of Jean-Baptiste Armand Louis Léonce Élie de Beaumont [25 September 1798 Canon, Calvados, Normandy, France – 21 September 1874 Canon, Calvados, Normandy, France], professor of geology at the College de France. Beaumont co-authored the Geologic Map of France and was an important researcher regarding the mechanics of mountain building. Beaumontite was re-investigated by Francis Alger in 1844 who discovered that the mineral was pseudo-orthorhombic and merely a crystallographic variant of heulandite.
Beaumontite (of L\u00e9vy).First Recorded Locality: ⓘ Jones Falls Quarries, Baltimore City, Maryland, USA
